results.title: 3 dances - Gulpilil
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Commonwealth Department of Aboriginal Affairs, Tom Manefield and David Roberts
results.brief_description: David Gulpilil performs three Aboriginal dances, Emu, Kangaroo and Fish. The first two are solo performances by Gulpilil and are closer to mime than dance. The third is a group dance with some of the children from Bamyili where Gulpilil lives in the Northern Territory.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Film Australia, Commonwealth Department of Aboriginal Affairs, Tom Manefield and David Roberts

results.title: 3-in-1: the path to reconciliation (A)
results.brief_description: This video contains a compilation of three videos produced for the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation to explain its vision and some of the major issues affecting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. “Walking together, produced by National Recording Studios, is an introduction to the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation; “Talkin’ Business”, produced by OZIRIS Productions, explains the Council’s consultation program, vision and key issues; “Making things right”, produced by National Recording studios, looks at reconcilation after the High Court decision on Native Title. Includes a 60 page guidebook, “The Path to reconciliation: Issues for a people’s movement”.

results.title: 2am feeding
results.brief_description: This film is a realistic look at parenting during the first few months after birth. It touches on a wide range of parental concerns, such as nursing, crying and colic, fatigue, mother’s recovery, sexuality, fathering, single parenthood, and returning to work. The film is straight forward, presenting a diverse group of new parents who relate their experiences with warmth and humour. Narrated by Robbie Engelmann.

results.title: 28 up
results.creator_credit: Michael Apted and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
Fourteen children from a variety of school backgrounds, interviewed in 1964 for television about their hopes and aspirations, are followed up twenty-one years later. Extracts from the interviews made when the children were seven, fourteen, twenty-one and twenty-eight years old are shown. Those involved, comment on any changes in their ideas. This film is suitable for years 11-12 and tertiary level.

results.title: 28 degrees above below
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Bane Jovanovic, David Bairstow and Ken Page
results.brief_description: Twenty-eight degrees above zero was the temperature below the sea ice, although surface temperature dipped to 50 below at Resolute Bay within the Arctic Circle when the MacInnis Expedition made its first organised winter dive in the polar sea to test the ability of man and his equipment to function in that extremely hostile environment. Commenting on the expedition is Dr. Joseph B. MacInnis himself, in brief conversation with astronaut Scott Carpenter. There is underwater footage of the dive and of Sub-Igloo, the plastic spherical habitat which was anchored to the ocean floor. (Awards: Milan)

results.title: 28 days later = twenty eight days later
results.creator_credit: Fox Searchlight Pictures, DNA (Korea), Film Council, Andrew Macdonald and Danny Boyle
results.brief_description: Upon waking after being in a coma for 28 days, bicycle courier Jim (Cillian Murphy) finds a completely different world. London is empty except for the virally infected zombies that want to murder everyone - and there aren’t many people left. Jim is rescued by Selena (Naomie Harris) who proves to be a strong and fearless survivor. The virus is passed on through blood and devastates within seconds, driving the infected into a murderous rage that essentially threatens human existence. But is the virus all that endangers the survivors? End-of-the-world survival tale done in a dark and sombre mood - a science-fiction horror story from the director of “Trainspotting” and “The Beach”, Danny Boyle. Cast includes Christopher Eccleston, Megan Burns and Brendan Gleeson. SOME SCENES MAY DISTURB.

results.title: 27 A
results.brief_description: A seminal work, one of the first quality productions after the rebirth of Australian film in the 70’s. It is the true story of a man locked in a mental asylum and held there until he can prove his eligibility to be released.

results.title: 26 times in a row
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Jean-Claude Labrecque and Jacques Bobet
results.brief_description: The Marathon has become a symbol of the Olympics. A modern-day addition to the Games, it commemorates the soldier who ran cross-country, in 490 B.C., to announce the Greek victory at Marathon and then died. Excellent film footage of the 1976 Olympic Marathon documents the physical demands of the race. Its emotional counterpart is related by Cierpinski, the event’s 1976 gold medalist. This emotion-charged film proves that although the winner of the Decathlon is the best all-round athlete, the “toughest” is the winner of the Marathon. (Award: Portland)
